title: Ted Nathanson
text:
Edward "Ted" Nathanson (1925 – June 6, 1997) was an American television director.
Biography.
Born Benedict Gimbel III to a <a href="American%20Jews">Jewish</a> family in Philadelphia, the son of Ethel S. (née Nathanson) and <a href="Benedict%20Gimbel%20Jr.">Benedict Gimbel Jr.</a> and the great-grandson of <a href="Adam%20Gimbel">Adam Gimbel</a> of the <a href="Gimbel%20Brothers">Gimbel Brothers</a> retailing family. His father was the president and general manager of WIP, one of the first radio stations in Philadelphia. He changed his name to Edward Nathanson (the surname of his mother) after his parents divorced. (His father remarried in 1931 to actress <a href="Sally%20Phipps">Sally Phipps</a> although they divorced in 1935). During World War II, he volunteered for the <a href="American%20Field%20Service">American Field Service</a> as an ambulance driver in Europe for Field Marshall <a href="Bernard%20Montgomery">Bernard Montgomery</a>'s <a href="Eighth%20Army%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Eighth Army</a>. After the war, he worked for <a href="CBS">CBS</a>, <a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a> and then <a href="NBC">NBC</a> where he directed the original "<a href="Tonight%20Show">Tonight Show</a>" and the "<a href="Today%20%28U.S.%20TV%20program%29">Today Show</a>."
He then became the coordinating producer of football and tennis for <a href="NBC%20Sports">NBC Sports</a>, where he directed 13 consecutive <a href="Super%20Bowls">Super Bowls</a>, 21 consecutive <a href="The%20Championships%2C%20Wimbledon">Wimbledon tennis championships</a>, the <a href="1972%20Winter%20Olympics">1972 Winter Olympics</a>, and the <a href="1988%20Summer%20Olympics">1988 Summer Olympics</a>. He also directed a wide variety of television shows including game shows, political conventions, and sporting events including <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20on%20NBC">major league baseball</a>, <a href="Boxing%20on%20NBC">boxing</a>, college football, <a href="NHL%20on%20NBC">hockey</a>, and <a href="Golf%20Channel%20on%20NBC">golf</a>. He was one of the first to utilize hand-held and remote-controlled cameras. He remained at NBC for 37 years.
He was the first person to receive the <a href="Directors%20Guild%20of%20America">Directors Guild of America</a> Lifetime Achievement Award for sports-related broadcasting.
Personal life.
He died on June 6, 1997 in <a href="Manhattan">Manhattan</a> of <a href="lung%20cancer">lung cancer</a>. He was survived by his wife, Edith (née Landesman), a producer he met while working at ABC; and three children, <a href="Michael%20Nathanson%20%28film%20executive%29">Michael Nathanson</a>, Laura Nathanson Knobloch, and Carla Nathanson Hoffman. All three of his children worked in the industry: Laura as Vice President at <a href="Fox%20Television">Fox Television</a>; Carla with the "<a href="David%20Letterman%20Show">David Letterman Show</a>"; and <a href="Michael%20Nathanson%20%28film%20executive%29">Michael</a> as president of <a href="MGM%20Pictures">MGM Pictures</a>. His wife died in 2020.
